title: voters blast tory blackmail claims
story: Exclusive: Voters blast Tory blackmail claims - Messing with kids futures is sickeningBury South MP Christian Wakeford dramatically quit the Tories to join Labour this week and claimed party enforcers had previously threatened him with losing cash for his constituency. Heres what voters thinkWaliko Banda, a care worker from Radclfe, said he was horried to learn school funding was threatenedthe MP didnt back the PM Image: Julian Hamilton Daily MirrorByAletha AduPolitical CorrespondentLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsAfter Tory Christian Wakefordaposs sensational defection to Labour, voters in his Bury South seat expressed fury at Boris Johnson and his party. Mr Wakeford quit the party in protest at the Prime Minister - and revealed that he had previously been threatened about the loss of a school in his constituencyhe did not vote with the Government on free school meals. His comments came as senior Tory William Wragg claimed rebels had been intimidated by party enforcers into toeing the party line. No  said: We are not aware of any evidence to support what are clearly serious allegations. If there is any evidence to support these claims we would look at it very carefully.But Mr Wakeford told the BBC : “I was threatened that I would not get the school for RadclfeI did not vote in one particular way.This is a town that’s not had a high school for the best part of  years.” It is understood that the vote was about a Labour motion to back Marcus Rashfordaposs free school meals campaign. The Red Wall Tory dramatically joined the Labour benches moments before PMQs on Wednesday.But what do his constituents in Bury South think  Why should we have to suffer because of their greed and hunger for power  Waliko Banda, a care worker from Radclfe, said he was horried to learn Mr Wakefordaposs school funding was threatenedhe didnapost back the Prime Minister. Iaposve got a three-month-old baby, and to think that his chances will be scuppered because of party politics is sickening, the -year-old said.  Why should we have to suffer because of their greed and hunger for power  I canapost agree and support a party that would do that to one of their own. What does that mean for the rest of us  He said he will struggle to choose a politician to back at the next election. Tories are acting like kindergarten childrenChristina Horner, , said shewill stick with voting for Keir Starmer at the next General Election.Ms Horner, from Stockport, said: I think the Tories are acting like kindergarten children. The Conservatives are hardly professional politicians.  I wish theyaposd focus on working people and poorer families.The Conservative Party always pretends to care, but itaposs clear they have no interests in anything apart from making their own pockets bigger.We saw it in the pandemic. Somehow the rich got richer. How does that level up the country  I want to know whataposs happening with the economy - not partiesGordon White, , retired from Radclfe, said:Iaposm sick and tired of hearing about these parties.I want to know whataposs happening with the economy. He had a party, so what! Is that going to solve the cost of living crisis  No. He got us through Covid, heaposs given us Brexit.I want to hear more about the good things he has in store for this country, not some unfounded allegations. Let politicians govern. Boris Johnson is toying with the country Marc Eulett, an accountant from Radclfe, said: Iaposve voted for the Conservatives and Labour in my letime. The -year-old said: Iaposve always been a swing voter but the latest party allegations have really done it for me. Boris Johnson is toying with the country. I canapost say Iaposm shocked but I feel embarrassed for us all, working people of this country. I wonapost say who Iaposve voted for but the next election will be tough. Sadly I do believe heaposll be able to walk away from these accusations as he does with most things. I still canapost believe a word he says Audrey Jolly, , from Radclfe is still unsureshe will vote Labour at the next election, having swung her normal Labour vote to back Mr Johnson at the  election. But Alison Jolly, , believes the Conservatives are unable to take care of the country. I thought Boris handled Covid really well but then the party allegations came out. I mean heaposs had such a rough start. Heaposs had Covid and heaposs got two little children. Itaposs been hard for him and heaposs doing the best he can.The fact that Dominic Cummings is coming out of the woodwork to try and accuse the PM of doing things, just says it all to be honest. But I still canapost believe a word he says because heaposs not being straightforward. To be honest my dad will be turning in his gravehe knew I voted Conservatives, and Boris has let me down. Alison said the Conservatives are behaving in a pathetic manner. Swanning off and having parties while the Queen was forced to bury her husband alone  What about the people who have lost loved ones to Covid  Itaposs not right at all and Iaposve had enough. I am so sick and tired of this Government. The fact that Mr Wakeford had to leave the party he was elected in says it all. news real-le-stories i-wear-adult-nappies-makes-"Man wears adult nappies at night due to his health conditionByBen ThompsonJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA man who has to wear adult nappies at night has finally accepted his health condition after initially blaming his incontinence on the dog. Marc Spaganuolo has spent the last  years struggling to control his bowels and his bladder - but stayed quiet about his condition because he was embarrassed. But now heaposs started making TikTok videos to let other people with incontinence know theyaposre not alone. Marc, , suffers from a degenerative nerve condition called peripheral neuropathy, meaning his brain doesnapost receive signals when the bladder and bowel are full. First suffering from incontinence when he was , he went through years of tests before finally getting his diagnosis when he was  years old.For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here Currently looking for love, Marc is even open and honest about his condition on his dating profile - claiming most people are open and understanding about it.  He said: It started with bed wetting. I tried to hide it and blamed it on my dog at first. My dog was elderly so I got away with that for a few months. Eventually, my dad found out and said aposWe need to take you to the doctorapos. I didnapost want to go, but my dad was saying it could be a urinary tract infection. That convinced me. It was embarrassment that stopped me wanting to go. It wasnapost like it was happening every night, it was sporadic at first. Here and there. Now itaposs daily. At first, Marc was told heaposd grow out of the condition, but as time went on, it became clear that wasnapost the case.  After a while of living with the condition, he discovered protective underwear, which he now wears daily. I believe in being upfront about it. I feel like those terminologies created a ide in my mind and kept me from dealing with it. Itaposs a diaper, letaposs own it, he said. To go through this as a teenager was an isolating experience. Over time, I would tell a person here and person there, my courage would grow. It was a decade long process of telling people here and there. It was hard to define a specic point where I got confident, but I want people to feel confident in talking about it. For Marc, the ultimate show of confidence was when he set up the TikTok account. Using the alias aposThe Diaper Dynamoapos, Marc explains how incontinence affects his day-to-day le and how he deals with aposself-diaperingapos.  Now, one of Marcaposs challenges is the world of dating - but his condition throws up problems. He said: One of the biggest challenges of my le is dating, because itaposs been such a gradual process for me to get to where I am now. But of course, Iaposd love to meet somebody. But through his TikTok, heaposs hoping to tap into a community and provide support to those who need it. He said: I started my TikTok in September . I knew people needed help with this stuff, and it took off from there. TikTokaposs algorithm was really good at finding people who needed this content. Marc now has , followers on the , with most people offering him support about his condition. Itaposs been a pretty wild ride, itaposs been eye opening in a few dferent ways, he said. But putting myself out there on TikTok and seeing the overwhelming amount of love and support made me realise I need to put myself out there and give people a chance to respond.  Itaposs been so many years that Iaposve been living with this and Iaposve gotten so used to talking about it in my everyday le that I knew showing this would be a big deal to helping people. This is a really common issue and thereaposs a reason why these products are made. Explaining incontinence affects between  and  million people around the world, he said parents have thanked him for his honesty, saying itaposs helped their children. I feel incredibly honoured when parents say my videos helped their kid. It sometimes brings a tear to my eye, he said. It wasnapost where I was intending to go with the content, but the fact that it has an impact on them is great. One woman said she showed it to her six-year-old and she responded aposIaposm not a freakapos. Thataposs the point. Evenyou have to live this way for the rest of your le, you can still find happiness and be who you want to be. Due to the unpredictable nature of his condition, Marc makes sure heaposs always prepared and keeps spare nappies and wipes to hand to clear up any accidents. He said: I keep diapers in a backpack, along with wipes. It depends where Iaposm going and what Iaposm doing, of course. I prefer and recommend diapers because Iaposve heard so many horror stories about catheters and stomas. I just think aposwhy go through that when I can manage with a diaper apos If Iaposm at a social event, I tend to be more discreet about it. I still get self-conscious from time to time. When I used to work in an office, Iaposd change midday in a private restroom.Do you have a real le story to share  Email jessica.taylor@reachplcWhile not everyone is kind about Marcaposs condition, many viewers of his videos are supportive. One person commented: You are inspiring. Thank you for normalising adult diapers. title: altered taste symptom omicron how
story: Is altered taste a symptom of Omicron  How to tell when your food tastes funnyThe Omicron iant has been found to have symptoms that are dferent from previous Covid strains. Is a change to your sense of taste a sign of Omicron  Here’s what you need to knowOmicron symptoms are more similar to a common cold Image: Getty ImagesByMalvika PadinTrends Writer:,  Jan | comments Since it began spreading in late November last year, the Omicron Covid iant has proven to be quite dferent than the previous strains of coronavirus.With symptoms that have been described as being more similar to a common cold, Omicron usually presents as a mild infection. However, the symptoms have been found very dferent from the classic three signs of Covid that we are used to.According to the NHS, the most common signs of coronavirus are a fever, new and continuous cough as well as a loss or change to sense of taste or smell.But is a change to your sense of taste a symptom of Omicron  Hereaposs everything you need to know Is altered taste a symptom of Omicron   A loss or change to your sense of taste or smell means that people who have coronavirus tend not be able to smell or taste anything properly, or things will smell or taste slightly dferent to normal. However, Omicron symptoms have been found to be dferent, with members of the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies , saying: There is some preliminary evidence emerging of changes in reported symptoms with Omicron infection. In particular, loss of taste or smell seem to be reported less frequently.  Professor Tim Spector of King’s College London, who is leading ZOE symptom appaposs Covid study, also warned that many people may not realise they have Covid. This is because Omicron symptoms are more similar to a common cold and donapost present with a cough, fever, or loss of taste or smell. Though symptoms of the virus have continued to change, there hasnapost been any updates made to the governmentaposs official symptoms list since last spring. How to tellyour sense of taste or smell has changed  An estimated , UK adults have been affected by a change or loss of sense of taste smell, according to Fth Sense, a charity for people affected by smell and taste disorders. The symptom means that food gives off an unpleasant odour or taste, such as rotten meat or chemicals. The specic cause for sensory loss is unknown, but a study published in the Nature Genetics journal suggests that genetics could be play an important role in a person experiencing loss or change in taste or smell after Covid infection. While smell training which involves snfing at least four distinctive smells to retrain the brain is one way to regain sensory loss, most people who experience smell and taste loss because of virus usually regain their sense spontaneously. What are the main symptoms of Omicron   The most common symptoms of Omicron, according to the ZOE Covid study are:Scratchy throat Runny NoseFatigue Body aches and pains SneezingOther reported signs of the iant include headaches, congestion, nausea and vomiting, skin rashes, night sweats, brain fog. The symptoms should last up to five days and be mild for most people. Getting enough rest and over-the-counter medication will help.However,your symptoms get worse and you are concerned, you can get advice from theNHS online , or by calling .Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Omicron iantCoronavirusNHSApps" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: bride often sent away doctors
story: Bride-to-be often sent away by doctors over  months before lump diagnosed as cancerHannah Grinsted, , who is due to get married in August, was diagnosed with breast cancer at  and now has been diagnosed with a second bout of the diseaseHannah is now urging people to trust their gut instinctthey think something is seriously wrong with them and to not take no for an answer Image: DEVON LIVE BPM MEDIAByAnita MerrittAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A brave -year-old Exmouth woman is currently fighting cancer for the second time in her short le after battling to be diagnosed on both occasions. Hannah Grinsted, who is due to get married in August, was diagnosed with breast cancer shortly after her st birthday.She claims she was repeatedly sent away by her GP over a period of five months in the belief that a lump in her armpit was being caused by something other than cancer.Following treatment, she began reliving her new le with the hope she had beaten cancer but tragically two years ago it ed, DevonLive reports.She has now been told her cancer is incurable, but treatments are available to prolong her le as much as possible with hope always around the corner of new trials. Hannah is now urging people to trust their gut instinctthey think something is seriously wrong with them and to not take no for an answer. Hannah, who previously worked for Avis Car Hire, recalled: I went to the doctors five to six times and I kept getting told it was a blocked gland or something to do with the deodorant I used, or it was related to my age and puberty.  I was not necessarily feeling poorly but I felt a lot of pain and I always thought that pain didnapost mean cancer but that isnapost the case. I was also suffering from pain down my back and front. Eventually I was referred to the RDE and a scan showed I had three tumours in my breast, and eight out my  lymph nodes had cancer in them so it was quite a lot. My first thought was that I was going to die. My mum was with me and she had an expression on her face I had never seen before. She was obviously very supportive and has been throughout my cancer journey. My whole world turned upside down in that moment and I went into a panic attack. Before Hannah began chemotherapy and radiotherapy in , due to her young age she was offered fertility treatment to preserve some of her eggs in case the treatment prevented her from being able to have children. Unfortunately, due to the severity of her cancer, Hannah was only able to have fertility treatment over a -day period which meant only four of her eggs have been able to be stored which greatly reduced her chances of becoming a mum. She also underwent a mastectomy and reconstruction surgery and had her lymph nodes removed. Hannah was later told she was in remission but says she never received a final scan to confirm the diagnosis.It was assumed I was cancer-free so I put on Facebook the good news, she said. I had not told anyone before then that I had cancer.However, around six months later while on a girly holiday in Ibiza, Hannah began experiencing severe problems with one of her legs. Suddenly she was unable to walk or put weight on it and kept falling over. On her , she went to her GP and said she had feared the cancer had ed, but says she was reassured it hadnapost and was sent home. After her leg showed no signs of improvement she was eventually referred back to hospital. On Christmas Eve , her worst fears were confirmed when she received a telephone call saying the cancer was back and this time it was in her femur. Hannah recalled: I was sat on my own at work on the late sht when I got the telephone call. When cancer gets into your bone itaposs incurable. I had a metal pole fitted into the centre of my femur because my bones are very brittle now. I also had one batch of radiotherapy and was on oral chemotherapy for about  months. The cancer held in my bone for about  months which was quite good, but about three months ago it was confirmed it had moved to my liver. Now itaposs also moved to my lungs, unfortunately, and the bottom of my pelvis.  It means that Hannah has started a course of intravenous chemotherapy treatment once a week for  weeks. This week she received her fth bout and has lost her hair again. In a bid to boost her spirits ahead of her upcoming wedding day in August, Hannahaposs cousin Sammi Williams has launched an online fundraiser called Help Hannah Fight Cancer. So far it has already raised more than £, of its target of £,. The fundraiser is being used to help make Hannahaposs big day the best it can be for her and her partner of nearly three years Charlie Cox,  - and it is also funding a luxurious handmade wig to help Hannah feel more confident. title: covid army veterans volunteers jabs
story: Jab volunteer Army veterans wise words for man having his first Covid vaccineFrom helping out at vaccination centres to using their valuable skills to help with logistics, veterans are playing a big part in the fight against Covid-If you haven’t already had your booster, now is the time to do itAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  As the Omicron iant continues to spread rapidly and more people book in their all-important vaccine booster, veterans, along with other volunteers, are doing vital work to help the NHS deliver the programme.Every adult in the country needs a booster dose, soyou haven’t already had yours, now is the time to do it.Just go to nhs.uk covidvaccination to book – and you can also make an appointment for --year-olds and help older teenagers get theirs too.Here we speak to some of the veterans about their work, starting with an ex-soldier who had two words for a man having his first jab which could inspire others to do the same... ‘Evenyou get five people vaccinated, that’s five people who won’t suffer’ Working for the ambulance service, I saw the effects of Covid- during the first wave – almost every patient we took in was ill with the virus. I was part of the Re:Act Disaster Response team who stepped up to help. The NHS was under the cosh at the time and I was part of the RE:ACT Disaster Response team who stepped up to help. I helped build the Nightingale hospitals in Wales and also worked with the local council in Hereford to distribute PPE. Now I’m at the pop-up vaccination centre in Hereford. There are two of us here who are ex-military – the other guy is an ex-submariner so we’ve got a broad range of skills. There’s not a lot that comes across our path that bamboozles us.The first time I volunteered was on a day off from work. We were tasked with letting people know about the vaccination centre, but of course we didn’t want to browbeat them so we let people come to us. Initially people thought we were giving out lateral flow tests – we’d say, No, we’re here for boosters or your first or second vaccination. It was quiet for the first hour, but word obviously spread around Hereford and by the end of the day I’d say we’d vaccinated about  people, from schoolkids upwards. I think . per cent of people were happy to have a vaccination. I thought: Evenyou get five people vaccinated, that’s five people who won’t suffer.” Yes, you might catch it, but you’re much less likely to end up in hospital. When people ask meI think it works, I feel like I can provide the back story for them.We’ve now even had people come in for their first jabs. I asked one, What changed your mind  He said,Omicron, because it’s more infectious’. I just said, “Well done.”So while I don’t strong-arm people, I do tell them, “I think you should get vaccinated. ‘We all need the booster so that le can get back to normal’  I joined the Royal Air Force in  and my last posting was out in Cyprus, but I always wanted to transition to a career in the NHS. Back in October  I joined the East of England Covid- mass vaccination programme and my first role was to provide support in the planning and delivery of large-scale centres, hospital hubs and community pharmacies. Now I’m working as the children’s project manager, leading and coordinating plans. This involves collating, analysing and improving plans, reporting to the programme director and the national team, using my past experiences to collaborate, advise and implement processes.  I’m good at seeing a problem and thinking outside the box to solve it. I can get parachuted into a project within the Covid- programme and am able to run with it. Every day is dferent, but that doesn’t faze me. I’m very adaptable and flexible – and I’ll give  per cent to achieving the common goal. Working with other people from the Forces means there’s a great sense of camaraderie. We share the same service ethos. If there’s a deadline, we’ll just knuckle down and get the job done. This is not a - job. Even though I might have to get up at .am to jump on a work call, I have no problem with that. I was motivated to join the Covid- programme by my sense of duty, and I’m really proud to be part of it. I have a passion for helping people and making sure things are completed to the highest standard. This gives me a real sense of achievement. I like being able to make a dference. The public response to getting boosted has been great, but there is still a long way to go. I believe the Get Boosted Now campaign is so important because we need to protect ourselves, the vulnerable and the future generations. We also need to get everyone boosted so we can get le back to normal as soon as possible. ‘One of my ex-soldiers gave me the Covid- jab’  I was  when I joined the Navy as a medic. It was the year after the Falklands War and I thought I’d like to get involved in something for the service of the country – to do what’s necessary when the time comes. As a Navy medic I was trained to deal with trauma from the very basic things up to the most drastic ones you could think of, like gunshots and traumatic amputations. After  years, I left in  to join the Army, then in  I moved to the NHS. During the pandemic I was initially asked to oversee the distribution of PPE. There were shortages across the board, and having worked overseas with the Royal Marines, my logistics knowledge came to the fore. I could make sure community midwives and health visitors had what they needed. In some cases this entailed doing the deliveries myself in the van!  For me, the pleasure in the role was being able to provide medical staff with the assurance that they would have the equipment they needed. I felt I was making a real dference. When the time came to get my Covid- jab, it was one of my former soldiers who gave me it. That was very impressive because when I met him he was , wide-eyed and fresh out of the box. When I next met him he was teaching the volunteers and St John’s Ambulance staff how to administer the vaccine. I was full of admiration for him. He’d stepped up as a young man and was teaching much more mature iniduals. But I wasn’t surprised – that’s what we expected our troops to do: step into the breach, wherever the breach happens to be. You can’t praise the veterans highly enough for getting involved in the vaccine campaign. They will serve their community in whatever circumstances, whether it’s dficult or easy. You’ve got a group of people who drop everything as soon as they’re asked, regardless of what their family commitment might be, and go and do the job. I don’t think there is a better resource for the country to draw upon.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON British ArmyRoyal Air ForceNHSRoyal MarinesFalklands WarNigel JonesJake WadeHelen RobertsHospitalsSoldiersArmed forcesTeenagersThe FalklandsMost ReadRecommended

news uk-news covid-cases-week-after-christmas-"Coronavirus in numbers: UK death toll rises by ByMatthew DreschNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsNew Covid cases in the UK averaged nearly half a million a day in the week after Christmas, almost three times the official figures, new analysis suggests. Meanwhile, health agencies have urged caution about interpreting the regular case numbers published each day for the UK, following changes in rules about testing.An average of , new cases of coronavirus per day were recorded from December  to January , according to the governmentaposs Covid- dashboard.But the true number of cases was likely to be nearer , a day, according to estimates by the Office for National Statistics . The sharp dference between the two figures shows just how many infections are being missed on the dashboard site. It comes as the government prepares to lt Plan B restrictions in England next week, meaning vaccine passports for large venues will end and people will no longer need to work from home.  Face masks will also no longer be a legal requirement from January .The move comes following increasing evidence the Omicron wave has peaked following a % drop in cases in a week.However, the number of infections on the governmentaposs Covid dashboard may be far lower than the actual figure. The dashboard only counts those people who have reported themselves as having tested positive for the virus.  This means the numbers are affected by how many people are coming forward for tests, have chosen to report their test results, or who are taking a test because they know they have coronavirus symptoms. By contrast, the ONS figures are based on analysis of nose and throat swabs taken from a representative sample of more than , people in private households. The same people are sampled every week, regardless of whether they know they have Covid- or have reported a positive result. The ONS then produces estimates of the likely number of new cases of coronavirus across the country. The estimates for the week after Christmas have only now been published, due to the time needed to collect and process the data.  The number of new cases reported by the government has always been lower than the level estimated by the ONS, but the gap has become wider since the arrival of the Omicron iant of the virus.In the week to November , before Omicron had started to spread in the UK, the ONS estimated an average of , new cases a day - just over twice the average of , a day recorded on the dashboard. The ONS estimates are now nearly three times the equivalent total on the dashboard. High levels of under-reporting will still be affecting the governmentaposs daily figures, meaning the true volume of cases in the UK is increasingly unclear. The recent change in the rules for testing, removing the the need for asymptomatic people to get a confirmatory PCR test after a positive lateral flow result, is also likely to affect the daily figures.  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter In its latest weekly Covid- surveillance report, the Health Security Agency said the removal of confirmatory PCR testing may affect case rates in England. Public Health Wales has estimated that removing the follow-up test is likely to reduce overall reported cases by at least %, based on analyses linking lateral flow tests to PCR positive episodes. The agency acknowledged that changes in testing behaviour may lead to under-reporting should symptomatic new cases not test using PCR. In Scotland, health officials have recently widened their method of counting new cases to also include people who have recorded a first positive lateral flow test - though this change has yet to be reflected in the figures published on the UK government dashboard. The dashboard numbers are currently limited to all positive lab-confirmed PCR test results in the UK, plus positive lateral flow tests in Northern Ireland and, in England, any positive lateral flow tests not followed by a negative PCR test taken within  hours. title: driving instructor slammed selling last
story: Driving instructor slammed for selling last minute test slots at five times the priceDriving instructor Steve Cogan has been branded selfish for advertising last minute driving test slots for highly inflated prices - but he says hes just the middle-manSteve Cogan said hes only trying to do good Image: Kennedy News Steve Cogan FacebookByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Jan | comments A driving instructor has come under fire after advertising last minute test slots for up to five times the price for learners wanting to beat the six month waiting list.Steve Cogan has been branded selfish for making money from desperate learners who are suffering from the ongoing backlog caused by the pandemic, but the dad-of-two claims he only wants to help. The instructor says he is trying to do good by helping learners in London to beat the current waiting lists, by advertising test dates given to him by an unnamed examiner - who is now being investigated by motoring chiefs.His Facebook marketplace listings posted repeatedly over the last two weeks contain a roll of  alleged February dates at  dferent centres, charging an eye-watering £ rather than the usual £ to £.  When Steve was contacted by undercover reporters posing as learners, he bragged that heaposs been selling tests from a very handy mystery examiner for a number of months and claimed he had tests available as soon as three days away their centres being booked up for months on the official system. He even claimed learners were engaging in bidding wars over the test slots, with one test going for as much as £. The Driver and Vehicle Standards Agencyconfirmed they are investigating the unnamed examiner, while it remains unclear how the unknown man is able to provide the slots to other instructors or whether he is breaching any rules or guidelines when doing so. Steve, who lives in Shepherdaposs Bush, said: Itaposs a six month waiting list so I was just trying to help some people out. Iaposm sure thereaposs people that would say itaposs fair and some people who say it isnapost.  I donapost buy the tests. Iaposm just a middle man. If you look at the DVSA and look who has bought them, my name wonapost be next to it. I go through someone . Iaposve got someone who lets me know theyaposve got these tests, then I pass them out to my students and anyone who needs them. I was just trying to help some people, and I only make £ from each booking and the rest goes to the other party. Itaposs not a huge amount of money. I thought I was doing people some favours by offering out the contact that Iaposve got. The guyaposs an examiner or an ex-examiner. I didnapost think it was dodgy, not really. Thereaposs hundreds of apps out there that you can get driving cancellations on. I just assumed it was one of those. A student got in contact with him, and then she put me in contact with him. Iaposm trying to do good. Some people will put the time in to press that refresh button and keep clicking, spending  hours a day doing it, and some people would rather pay someone  to do it. If itaposs not allowed then I will happily stop right now. I donapost want to get in trouble and I donapost want to get anyone  in trouble. I donapost want to get on the wrong side of anyone, let alone the DVSA. Driving tests cost £ to be taken on a weekday and £ for a weekend, but by paying an extra £ and providing your provisional driving licence and theory pass numbers Steve says he can help jump the queue. London resident Aleksandrs Krasuckis, whose partner Korina Anderson has had to wait from September until next month to take her test three hours away from home, has branded Steveaposs actions as selfish. Aleksandrs said: Heaposs being selfish and taking advantage of desperate learners. Who is he doing the right thing for  It must be himself because heaposs earning money from it. When the price is that high, itaposs not the right thing for everyone. I was just p***** off with this kind of person, keeping the slots for themselves. I understand itaposs quicker and thataposs a good thing but itaposs too high of a price for me. The DVSA should be looking into it, and maybe the trainees should book the test themselves and not the driving instructor. It would cut out this kind of thing. Steven claims heaposs been called aposkindapos for providing the quick-booking tests to learners and even suggests the DVSA should begin to operate it in the same way airlines provide priority boarding. However Steve deleted his initial Facebook listing after being informed of the DVSAaposs investigation into the unnamed examiner. A DVSA spokesperson said: DVSA does not stand for any abuse of our customer service booking systems and are investigating. We will not hesitate in taking actionany misconduct is identied. We will take action against any instructor guilty of misconduct at the expense of legitimate candidates who have patiently waited for their opportunity to test. Any tests booked outside of the official DVSA booking site could be a scam and may result in candidates not having a test slot. We urge anyone to report any tests offered on social media to us.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. news uk-news family-use-kettle-wash-theyve-"Family use kettle to wash after being left with no hot waterByHannah Neary:,  Jan | comments A mum and her three children have been left without hot water and heating since Boxing Day after suffering from constant leaks in their run down home. Care worker Lorraine King, , and her kids have had to wash themselves with hot water from a kettle since their home in West London was damaged by a leak.She told MyLondon: I’ve got to either boil the kettle or even go and take a bath at my daughter’s which is miles away. It’s not convenient.Lorraine, who works in care, said her home, owned by the Catalyst Housing association, has flooded at least once a year since she moved in. She said: It’s happened in the front room three times and also the bedroom, bathroom, toilet. It’s just constant. -  She said the latest incident happened on Boxing Day, when water flooded through the ceiling of her front room where her granddaughter was playing. Lorraine lives with her son and two daughters and they are still waiting for their home to be fixed and claims sheaposs had no advice on when it will be sorted.She also said multiple maintenance workers have come to the property since but no one has fixed the issue and there seems to be poor communication across the company.  She added: The repairs take extra long to do. The guy left us with no hot water or heating. Then they contacted me two weeks later and told me they weren’t aware we didn’t have any heating. They gave us these little oil heaters, which don’t heat up the room at all. The whole house really does smell because of the flood. According to Lorraine, someone came to look at the problem weeks later and turned the electricity back on within a few hours another leak happened.  She said: The whole thing was flooded. There was no advice. I’ve still got no heating or hot water. Every contractor who comes says they don’t know anything about it and they’ve just come to assess it. Clearly they’re not communicating. Lorraine said she is worried a family member could be electrocuted because of the damp conditions and the stress of the repeated leaks is affecting her mental health. She said: It’s happened so much, I’m now having mental health issues and I never had this before I moved into the property. On Saturday, I had a total meltdown because I just couldn’t handle it any more and I’ve still got to come into work. I can’tproperly because I don’t feel myself.  Lorraine says she was on the housing waiting list for  years before she moved into her first permanent home in Kensington and Cha in . But she said the new build has had so many defects she almost cannot stand to live there any more. She said: Eventhey repair it I’m not comfortable in that property because I’ll decorate it and it’ll be ruined again. A spokesperson for Catalyst said: “We are sorry for the inconvenience and distress caused. We believe the source of the current problem is a leaking communal heating pipe in Ms King’s ceiling. To permanently fix the pipe, we need to take down the ceiling, and we are speaking with Ms King to arrange for adequate access to her home and enough time to complete the work and replace and redecorate her ceiling.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Mental healthFloodspovertyHousing" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: farmers slam mcdonalds after being
story: Farmers slam McDonalds after being forced to take off boots before enteringThe group said they were "shocked" when an employee for the fast food chain - which prides itself on sourcing produce from British farms - reportedly told them they had to remove their boots before eatingA group of teen farmers were shocked when they were told to remove their boots before entering a McDonalds in Crewe Image: MEN MEDIAByJosh PenningtonRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A group of teen farmers say they were stunned when McDonaldaposs staff reportedly refused to serve them unless they took off their work boots - which they say were clean.The farming students said they were hungry and looking forward to a burger and fries at the Crewe branch of McDonaldaposs last Monday, when staff are said to have stopped them at the door.They were shocked when an employee for the fast food chain - which prides itself on sourcing produce from British farms - reportedly told them they had to remove their boots before eating, Cheshire Live reports.A member of staff insisted so the teens left their footwear outside the front door, they said. The Reaseheath Agricultural College students claim they saw local builders were allowed in for a meal while wearing filthy boots. Teen farmer Jamie Goode, , from Holmes Chapel, said: “We were shocked when they wouldn’t let us in. We just laughed at them. “This lady was standing there and said that before we could enter, we had to take our boots off.  All our boots were clean and certainly not mucky but they insisted they wouldnapost let us in unless we took them off. There were a lot of workmen going in with their boots on, and theirs were filthy. Jamie believes someone from his college may have told restaurant staff to stop students entering with their boots on. He said: When we asked why [we couldnapost go in], they said Reaseheath [college] said we should be told to take our boots off. “But when we got back, the college said they knew nothing about such an instruction. They said it was probably a health and safety issue to ask to take our boots off, but this is not rightthey are allowing the building trade inside with their boots. He added: “We don’t even understand how they knew that we were from the college – we didn’t have our ID badges on or anything. A spokesperson from McDonaldaposs said: “We are proud supporters of British and Irish agriculture and work with over , farmers across the UK and Ireland. We have a strong relationship with the local Agricultural college and we have an agreement in place to ensure students that visit our restaurant remove their wellington boots, to ensure the restaurant maintains the high standards that all our customers expect. We greatly appreciate the cooperation of the college and students, and look forward to continuing to welcome them to our restaurant in the future.” The Mirror has contacted McDonaldaposs for further comment. title: herd abandoned donkeys who faced
story: Edenfield Ramsbottom, Readers have raised money for a new roof at the sanctuary Molly the Mule" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Donkey_AJPG.jpg" width"" "" The animals at Bleakholt Animal Sanctuary now have a warm home thanks to Sunday People readers Image: Reach CommissionedByAmanda Killelea:,  Jan | comments A herd of abandoned donkeys finally have a new roof over their heads thanks to big-hearted Sunday People readers.Before Christmas we told how rescue donkeys Flash, Fergus and their pals were facing a soggy and cold start to  due the leaky asbestos-ridden roof on their shelter at Bleakholt Animal Sanctuary in Edenfield, Lancs. But the charity which is home to hundreds of rescued dogs, cats, horses, rabbits  goats could not afford the £, needed for the urgent repairs. So the sanctuary’s chairman, actress and Strictly star Gemma Atkinson, launched a fundraising appeal, backed by the Sunday People, to raise the cash.  After the donkeys and their plight featured in the People, donations began to flood in and the sanctuary has been able to give the donkeys the home they deserve so they can live out the rest of their lives in luxury. Actress Gemma told the People: “Everyone has been so generous to help our donkeys at Bleakholt. The donkeys are all real characters and deserve to have the best lives as many were abandoned or neglected in the past. “For people to have helped financially to make sure the stable is dry, weather-proof and snug for our donkeys, means a lot. They live out their lives at Bleakholt and now they have updated conditions to continue being well cared for.”  Sanctuary Manager Karen Weed added: “Thanks to the Sunday People we raised over our target and the donkeys are now living in lovely modernised stable with no rain coming in! “We have been able to get the roof fully done and now are looking to put new doors in place and repair the floor too. “It was an old building so all the donations have been a major boost and the donkeys love it. “We have donkeys and mules who have been abandoned but now they can live their lives out at our sanctuary in an up-to-date stable where they will be snug and content.” The new stable is a real boost for Flash who has barbed wire scars on his body from a past le. Fergus was seen being beaten up at a horse sale eight years ago and was bought by a kind person and given to Bleakholt.  “We love our donkeys and mules as they all have such dferent characters and personalities,” said joint Head of Stables Natalie Hill. “We have Hughie, a Mediterranean miniature donkey, who loves Ana, the only female donkey, and defends her honour. “There is Marty the mule who was living in a housing estate in Newcastle and being ridden around by children before he was brought here. “We have just got two new mules, two females as we are overrun by males! They have come from the Donkey Sanctuary – they are Dottie, who was abandoned at Appleby Fair, and Molly who was relinquished due to a previous owner’s change of circumstance. “They are settling in and we do have ‘donkey social workers’ from the Donkey Sanctuary who come and check that their donkeys and mules are all good.”The sanctuary always needs donations to cover the cost of looking after all their reduced animals. To sponsor a Bleakholt donkey or mule, or any animals, go to https:www.bleakholt.org help sponsorship  Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Sunday PeopleGemma AtkinsonCharitiesAsbestosAnimals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get all the Strictly glitter and goss straight to your inbox with our Strictly Come Dancing newsletterSubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: historic street could renamed after
story: Calls for offensive road name to be changed after two visitors complainLton Parish Council has written to residents after two visitors to the village complained of the name of Darkey Lane and have askedthey want to change it or notResidents in Lton, Devon are being askedthey want to change the name of the road Darkey Lane Image: Google.MapsByAnita MerrittAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  Residents in a Devon village are facing calls to change the offensive name of a road after complaints made by two visitors. Lton Parish Council has written to residents about the complaints of aposDarkey Laneapos and have askedthey want to change it or not. If residents choose to rename the road, it would be the responsibility of West Devon Borough Councilwhich would then do their own consultationa desire for change was expressed, DevonLive reports. The letter from January  reads: I have been asked to write to you on behalf of Lton Parish Council following receipt of a complaint about the street name Darkey Lane made by two visitors to the village. What do you think about this story  Let us know in the comments below  The visitors, one of who is of Caribbean heritage, were shocked and extremely upset having been confronted with a name like this. Councillors took the decision at a parish council meeting on November , , to undertake a public consultation with you in early January , to find outyou would like to keep or change the existing road name. It went on to explain that to rename the road, two-thirds of households on Darkey Lane would have to be in agreement. for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email.Furthermore,they wanted to change the name then each household would have to pay £ to WDBC. The parish council have offered to pay for replacement road signs. Residents on the road would also be required to tell utility companies and all professional and personal contacts regarding any new road name. In the same letter, the parish council gave historical context on how the road got its name. It said: Darkey Lane was a historic, locally-based road name given before development in the local area. The road had originally been a sunken and tree-lined dark lane. Over the years and with the use of local Devonshire dialect, it became known as Darkey Lane. Robert Fleming, the owner of Lton Hall Hotel, is in favour of changing the roadaposs name. He said: I agree that the name should be changed. I think historically that the lane may have been called Darke Lane in the old English spelling, as indeed the lane is very dark and tree covered in places. The fact that the word ‘darkey’ has negative connotations, and has and continues to be used as such, supersedes historical spellings where they may have had a dferent meaning. People may be offended so it should be changed as standard, with a minimum of fuss. Indeed as a hotelier in the area, we have had people actually mention their surprise at the name of the lane as it is quite close to us. When I moved here  years ago I remember being rather shocked at it as we had moved down from London and lived in a multi-racial area of East London. Lton can not by any stretch of the imagination be classed as multi-racial. For people objecting to the change, I thinkthey could imagine themselves as being in a minority of some sort and then have a derogatory work on a street name that affected  upset them it may garner a dferent response. The name could be just Darke Lane or even Dark Lane which is minimal effort. In this advanced age we live in it should be a simple matter to change all the databases etc, although people may decide to live with it as it means changing passport  drivers licences and so on which obviously will incur some costs. Lton Parish Council said the results of the consultation will be reported at its next meeting later this month on January . news uk-news lava-field-size-football-pitch-"Ayrshire: Smoke pours from ground as lava-like field burnsByRyan ThomAyrshire Post Senior ReporterEstel Farell-Roig:,  Jan | commentsA field that has been burning with a lava-like substance for three years has been described as a serious risk to le by a dad. The worried parent captured the smouldering soil on camera this week and claimed thatyou were to fall into that there would be nothing left of you. Council chiefs said that a disused coal mine beneath the site is to blame for the burning of the field in East Ayrshire, in south-west Scotland. The field in Patna - which is on land owned by Forestry Land Scotland - continues to burn despite temperatures plummeting to below freezing in January.Dad Tam Paton has now claimed the area has been burning for more than three years and called for the fire to be put out, reports the Daily Record. The -year-old says mass parts of the area have aposfallen awayapos and aposturned to dustapos due to the searing heat. Shocking footage has shown smoke pouring out from the field which is just a  minute walk away from the village centre. Red hot pockets of a substance described like lava can be seen in pictures and videos taken by Tam.Tam told Ayrshire Live : “It’s been burning solid for the best part of three and half years. “It doesn’t matter how cold it gets, when we have snow it just melts away instantly. “It becomes worse in the summer months. “The smell is potent. You can smell the ground burning the minute you get near the field. “Bits of it have all turned to dust and fallen away. “It is over a vast area, about the size of a football pitch and itaposs only getting bigger.  Tam worries that the deadly field will lead to a tragedy one day. The dad claims that the Scottish Coal Board have tried to fence off the danger zone.  He added: “If you were to fall into that there would be nothing left of you. “It’s a real danger particularly with it being a popular spot for dog walkers and a lot of the kids like to go up that way at the weekend. “It would just take one wrong move and it would be a disaster. There is only two poles and a wee wire fence, it is definitely not enough protection from an area so dangerous. A spokesperson for East Ayrshire Council said: East Ayrshire Council was first made aware of this issue last summer and since then has continued to engage with both the landowner,, and the Coal Authority as the relevant regulatory body for such issues arising from former coal mining works, in order to ensure that the situation continues to be managed and to minimise any risk to public health and safety . In that regard the council is aware that appropriate safety measures were put in place, including fencing around the affected area, but unfortunately that has since been removed by unknown parties, which clearly isn’t helpful. The council will continue to engage with the relevant parties to ensure they fulfil their respective obligations, and in the meantime would advise members of the public to avoid the affected area and also ask them not to interfere with any safety measures which are, or might be put, in place for their own protection. Ayrshire Live contacted the UK coal mining community response team and Scottish First and Rescue for comment. title: mum 27 told not see
story: Mum, , told she may not live to babys birthday after tired, bloated feelingEstelle Wignall has defiantly insisted she is up for the fight and has launched a fundraising campaign to seek treatment for her oian cancer and terminal illness overseasYoung mum Estelle Wignall with husband Mike Image: Focus FeaturesByAnn CusackGraeme Murray:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A young mum fighting cancer has been warned she will not see her daughter’s next birthday. Estelle Wignall has stage four oian cancer which recently spread to her bowel and doctors have told her she is terminally ill.A mum to baby daughter, Brooke,  months, she has been offered palliative care.But Estelle insists she is up for the fight, and has launched a fundraising campaign through GoFundMe to seek treatment overseas.She says: “I feel as though I have been written off, but I am not ready to throw in the towel yet. I’ve bounced back before, and I am determined to do it again. To help Estelle raise money for treatment overseas, you can donate here. I want to celebrate my little girl’s second birthday, I want to see her start school, I want to mark as many milestones as I can.” Estelle, , from Wigan, Greater Manchester, was diagnosed with oian cancer five years ago after becoming tired and bloated. Doctors at first insisted she had IBS but her symptoms became so bad that she was rushed to hospital and then sent home again with medication. She said: “I picked up a leaflet in hospital about oian cancer and I immediately diagnosed myself. But everyone told me not to be so stupid because I was only  years old. “People said I was being a hypochondriac. Nobody took me seriously – but I just knew. It was an instinct.” Estelle pushed for tests and in February , she was finally diagnosed with grade one oian cancer. She had a tumour removed, along with her right oy and Fallopian tube. After making a full recovery, she put the cancer behind her, working as a receptionist and marrying soulmate Mike, , in June  in Texas. The couple had their first child, Brooke, in May . Estelle said: “I had only one oy and so to conceive so quickly felt like a miracle. I didn’t have my regular checks because I was pregnant, and during the birth the midwe actually noticed nodules on my cervix and I was referred for more tests, which came back clear. “We adored Brooke and the future looked fantastic.  “I was actually planning a hysterectomy so that there was no chance the cancer could .” But before her op, Estelle started to feel unwell, suffering from exhaustion and a lack of appetite. She said: “I had started the  week diet challenge, to get rid of my baby weight. I just needed to lose a stone, that was all. “But I started to feel very tired and I had no appetite. I thought it was all due to the diet – but it got worse and I began to think the cancer might be back.” In November , she was sent for urgent scans and was diagnosed with stage four cancer, which had spread to her liver and lungs.  She said: “I was devastated. The first time I had cancer, I coped well. But this time, because of Brooke, I was heartbroken. She was just six months old and it felt so cruel. I had only just started being a mum, and I didn’t want it to be taken away. She was initially told her le expectancy was only two or three years but her outlook improved after treatment and a raft of alternative therapies. “There have been points when I felt I could not go on. I considered euthanasia. But I kept going, and I got my spirits up again, she said. A recent scan showed the cancer has spread once again to the bowel and Estelle is now being warned that her time is fast running out. She says: “I’ve been on the brink before and I have bounced back and I am determined to do it again. I can’t give up, I have too much to live for, and I am determined to look for treatment abroad. “I hope also that my story can help other women, it is so important, no matter how young you are, to follow your instincts and to insist on answers. Don’t be fobbed off – it could cost you your le.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Oian cancerCancerHospitals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news mum--uninhabitable-vermin-infested-"Leicestershire: Rats scurry around mum’s kitchenByFinvola Dunphy:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A desperate family-of-seven have been forced to sleep in their car after discovering their flat is infested with vermin.Kay Kennerson-Neal, , claims her home, which is above a derelict pub, is uninhabitable with smashed windows and rats. So she, her husband and kids have left the privately-rented apartment in Donisthorpe, Leicestershire, to sofa surf and even sleep in their car at times.But North West Leicestershire Council, controlled by the Conservative Party, says the family are not a priority because they are not at a genuine risk of homelessness. Speaking to Leicestershire Live, worried Kay said: Iaposm heartbroken. Myself and my partner are in tears every single day. We havenapost slept there since December  as we were horried. There are rats everywhere. When we first saw the rats, we all screamed and were horried. I rang the council but nobody believed me. I had to go out and buy a camera which I set up in the kitchen to capture them. They were all over the kitchen surface, floor and even in the cupboard where I keep my pots and pans.  Kay claims her children, aged , eight, three, two and five-months-old, have suffered sickness and diarrhoea as a result of the vermin. And she doesnapost want to risk their health by staying there any longer despite, she says, still having to pay the £ monthly rent. The landlord says it is not clearthe vermin are rats or field mice and they are working very closely with the environmental team and emergency housing team who are satisfied with the living conditions. But Kay continued: My children got so poorly - diarrhoea and vomiting that I had to take them out. Mentally, Iaposm breaking down. Every day my husbandaposs mental health is through the roof. My kids donapost know where they are sleeping from night to night. They scream when they have to go in there. I just canapost call it home anymore. I want out now. We keep being told we are not a priority. I have young children and a five month old, I donapost see how this is possible. I just want a safe place to live for myself, my husband and my children. Kayaposs mother-in-law, Ruth Neal says she is heartbroken for what her loved ones have had to go through. The gran said: Iaposm worried sick for my family. They have had it rough for the last four weeks. Iaposve had both my son and daughter-in-law in tears every single day and every time they enter the building, my grand kids are ill. I just want them all in a safe environment. The council should be providing emergency accommodation for them. I just want to see my family happy and safe.  A spokesperson for Kayaposs landlord said: We have been working very closely for quite some time with the environmental team and emergency housing to address any concerns from the tenants. Pest control has been out and the environmental team have inspected the property and are happy with the living conditions. Inside the property, there is a large hole in the kitchen floor which was not there before the tenants moved in. They have been advised to cover this up as it suspected that this is how the vermin are entering the property. Similarly, the tenants have been advised to clear away some rubbish that has been left out which could attract the vermin. The council have received all the reports of all inspections that have been carried out and they are very happy with the progress we have been making. There are a few jobs that we need to do and there have been tradesmen at the property every day this week working on them. The environmental team also inspected the downstairs of the Masons and found no infestation.Andy Barton, Strategic Director atNorth West Leicestershire District Council, said: We canapost comment on inidual circumstances, but we are aware of the familyaposs situation and are working with them and are in touch with the landlord to ensure the property is safe and habitable.Rental homes must be fit to live in and kept in a reasonable state of repair, so where properties do not meet this standard we work with tenants and their landlords to make improvements. If someone is threatened with homelessness within  days we will work with them to try and prevent homelessness either by assisting them to remain where they are or by supporting them in a planned move. title: one uks most wanted men
story: One of UKs most wanted men The Big Guy arrested in Spain  hours after public appealThe Big Guy Joshua Hendry, , from Liverpool, was spotted walking a dog in Marbella, Spain, on Thursday with police later arresting him in the town of San Pedro de AlcantáraJoshua Hendry has been arrested in Spain after the National Crime Agency issued an appeal Image: Liverpool ECHOByTom DuffyMatthew DreschNews ReporterNatalia Penza:,  Jan  One of the UKaposs most wanted fugitives has been arrested in Spain less than  hours after being named in a police appeal.Joshua Hendry, , from Liverpool, who is said to be known as aposThe Big Guyapos, was spotted by an off-duty police officer in Marbella.The Spanish National Policeaposs fugitives unit arrested him in the town of San Pedro de Alcantára on Thursday, the Liverpool Echo reports.It comes less than a day after the National Crime Agency- Britainaposs equivalent of the FBI - named Hendry on a list of  fugitives on the run in Spain.Hendry, who was wanted by Humberside Police, allegedly trafficked heroin and cocaine from Liverpool to Grimsby for onward distribution.Spanish police said Hendry was arrested after a man with his physical characteristics was seen walking a dog.  Footage has been released of him being escorted through an underground car park by a single police officer, wearing a mustard green tracksuit top and bottoms. He has been taken into custody and will appear in court soon as part of extradition proceedings. Confirming the detention, a Spanish National Police spokesman in Malaga said: “One of the  fugitives on the UK’s Most Wanted list of criminals in Spain has been held. “The detention took place less than  hours since the start of a new edition of the Most Wanted operation. Tom Dowdall, NCA Deputy Director of International, said: “This is a rapid result and it’s testimony to the power these appeals can have as well as the NCA’s international reach. “Whether it’s using tip-offs from the public, sharing intelligence or deploying specialist capabilities, UK law enforcement and our Spanish partners are working as one to trace and arrest the other  fugitives. “Those men will know now that we’re after them. They can live their lives anxiously looking over their shoulders and wonderingtoday’s the day they get caught or they can do the right thing and hand themselves in.”  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Chief Inspector Rhodri Troake of Humberside Police said: “We’d like to thank the National Crime Agency for their assistance in locating and arresting Hendry as a part of an efficient and fast-moving operation. “Hendry is alleged to have trafficked heroin and crack cocaine from Liverpool to Grimsby for onward distribution within our local communities. “This type of criminality can cause signicant disruption to our local communities and we will continue to do everything we can to continue to bring those responsible to justice.” Anyone with information about any of our Most Wanted can contact theCrimestoppers anonymously on   , and callers in Spain should call the freephone Spanish number   . There is also the online reporting form which can be completed via crimestoppers-uk.org fugitives.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Crime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: prince andrews cuddly toy collection
story: Prince Andrews cuddly toy collection would make most women run a mileRachael Bletchly says an insider has revealed that Prince Andrew still sleeps with a little gang of furry friends, with staff keeping a list of instructions on where to place the toysAn insider claimed Prince Andrew sleeps with some cuddly toys Image: Getty ImagesopinionByRachael Bletchly:,  Jan The Duke of York and his ex-we Fergie are apparently planning to remarry. Which is just as well as he’s NEVER going to find a new squeeze after the latest bedroom revelations. Not the sex abuse ones which, of course, Prince Andrew vehemently denies and still has a chance to defend himself in a US legal action. But in the court of public opinion he has been well and truly stuffed by the details of his cuddly toy fetish. A former servant has disclosed that ­after his orce from Fergie in  Andrew kept a ­collection of  teddies and other ­animals lined up with ­military precision on his Buckingham Palace bed.  Every night the maid had to move the heir bear bunch to set positions around the room so that they “looked pretty”. The small ones dressed in sailor unorms were ranked by size order in an unused fireplace and his two favourite bears sat on ickle thrones on either side of the bed. Then, in the morning, she had to put them all back again, using a diagram to ensure they were correctly positioned. Becauseso much as a whisker was out of place the Queen’s favourite son would scweam and scweam like a toddler having a tantrum. This all sounded so bizarre that I ­wonderedAndrew was going through some sort of post-orce breakdown at the time – especially as the maid says he also kept Fergie’s make-up on his dressing table and her wedding gown in the wardrobe. But another insider has revealed that Andrew STILL sleeps with a little gang of furry friends. And staff also keep a list of instructions showing where Heart-Holding Teddy sits and how Grey Hippo should be placed on the bed on top of a special green blankie.  Crikey. I know that ­millions of grown men still cherish a childhood teddy. But Andrew’s menagerie would make most women run a mile. Because we all know there is something deeply dodgy about a bloke who keeps piles of soft toys on his bed. It suggests that he still sucks his thumb, likes wearing nappies and will want to call you Mummy while you dust his bottom with talcum powder. But I’m sure loyal Sarah is well used to Andy’s Toy Story fantasies by now. So we can only hope that they tie the knot soon – and buzz off to infinity and beyond. news uk-news prince-andrews-ex-maid-says-"Prince Andrew stripped of military titles and royal patronagesByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  A former Buckingham Palace maid says she has no regrets about speaking out against Prince Andrew and described him as a horrible man.Charlotte Briggs claimed the Duke of York often erupted into demanding and entitled foul-mouthed rants which left her in tears.The -year-old, who lives in Halax, West Yorkshire, made front-page news this week when she revealed her experiences doing the job nobody wanted six months after starting work for the royals in January .She described the Queenaposs second son as a spoiled brat who once allegedly - after noticing sheaposd left a gap in the curtains - fumed: Can’t you f***ing do anything right  Charlotte says since then she has been ridiculed in her hometown and accused of selling out.Do you enjoy reading about the royal family for all the best royal news from the Mirror here  But believes she is entitled to speak about what happened to me even though it was years ago. Charlotte has also been keen to point out while she considered Prince Andrewaposs attitude poor, she never witnessed any inappropriate behaviour. The Duke is facing a civil trial after being accused of sexual abuse by a trafficking victim of his late paedophile pal billionaire financier Jeffrey Epstein. Virginia Giuffre is suing Andrew for allegedly having sex with her in the US when she was .  He vehemently denies her allegations and has not been charged with any criminal offence.Speaking to the Daily Mail outside her home on Friday, Charlotte said: I donapost give a toss what Prince Andrew feels…he is a horrible, nasty man.She explained she had signed a privacy agreement under the Official Secrets Act not to ulge any accounts of her time at the Palace. But on seeing ITVaposs documentary this week - which included claims by another ex-staff member that Andrew had a map for exactly where his cuddly toys needed to be on the bed - she decided to breach it.The mum-of-two said: I am not sorry at all. But I have been hurt by some of the remarks against me. In her original interview, she said Andrewaposs brothers Prince Charles and Prince Edward, as well as all other royals she encountered, were wonderful. She was just  when she started work at the Palace and started working for Andrew when he was  - at a time when he had recently orced from Sarah Ferguson. Charlotte was paid £ a month and was pictured on the royal balcony ahead of the Trooping the Colour ceremony the same year. It comes as the Queen stripped the Duke of his royal titles and patronages ahead of his trial in New York and he is facing eviction from the Royal Lodge in Windsor. Buckingham Palace declined to comment on Charlotte Briggsapos accusations when approached by the Mirror. news uk-news prince-harry-losing-role-final-"William and Harry: Tensions existed before arrival of MeghanByBradley JollyNews Wire:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsPrince Harry would face no going back to his former royal leheaposs axed as a Counsellor of State, itaposs claimed.The Duke of Sussex, , is one of four Counsellors of States, alongside Prince Charles, Prince William and Prince Andrew. These royals, as the next four people in the line of succession who are over the age of , would undertake The Queenaposs official duties as Sovereign on a temporary basis due to illness or absence abroad.But there are questions whether Harry is eligible as he now lives, for the most part, in the US with we Meghan Markle. The pair stepped back as senior members of the royal family in .And it has now been claimed this would be a catastrophic blow for Harry, who it emerged last year has relinquished his royal patronages.Being removed, by parliament no less, as a Counsellor of State would really be the nail in Harry’s coffin of his former le as a frontline member of the royal family, a source told the Daily Mail. If the Queen does take steps to have this situation remedied and Harry is axed, there really is no going back. All of these decisions – the military titles, the HRHs in abeyance – could theoretically be reversed. However, having parliament take formal action to remove them as Counsellors of State is in another league entirely.  The prince, who married Meghan in May  and since had two children with the former actress, left his royal titles in the UK two years ago.Itaposs still unclearHarry and Meghan, , will join the Queen and the rest of the family for Prince Philipaposs memorial to be held on an as yet unspecied date.It comes as the Sussexes have raised concerns over their security back in the UK, with Harry claiming an offer to pay for his own was previously refused. In , the Queenaposs father King George VI created the Regency Act which decided the Counsellors of States in their current model. Counsellors of State can attend Privy Council meetings, sign routine documents and receive the credentials of new ambassadors to the United Kingdom. title: queen ordered petulant andrew back
story: Queen ordered petulant Andrew to back down over royal loo dispute with CharlesFormer Buckingham Palace maid Janette McGowan said during Christmas  at Sandringham, Prince Andrew put his toiletries in the bathroom meant for Prince Charles and refused to move themPrince Andrew is said to have once refused to move his toiletries from a bathroom meant for brother Charles Image: Getty ImagesByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Jan Prince Andrew once had to be ordered down by the Queen in a bizarre squabble with older brother Charles over a toilet, it has been claimed.The Duke of York, aged  at the time of the alleged incident, refused to remove his toiletries from a royal bathroom at Sandringham meant for the Prince of Wales and future king. He finally relented when his mum intervened, according to an ex-maid. Former Buckingham Palace staff member Janette McGowan - who had travelled with the Firm to the residence in Norfolk - revealed Andrewaposs childish tantrum, said to have happened over Christmas . She said astonished colleagues were alerted to the situation after the Duke put his things into the wrong bathroom and then refused to move them.Do you enjoy reading about the royal family for all the best royal news from the Mirror here  Charles would have been  at the time.Ms McGowan told The Sun : We were told not to move anything and not to touch anything in that bathroom because there was an aposongoing situationapos.She explained that when members of the family travel to Sandringham - where the monarch usually hosts her annual festive lunches - they are each allocated rooms and bathrooms. But on this occasion Andrew took the wrong one and wouldnapost budge, the former maid continued, adding: It turned into a bizarre stand-off.  In the end, the Queen herself had to intervene to defuse the situation. She actually had to have words with Andrew and say to him that he had to use the other bathroom and that was when he finally backed down. He was almost  at the time. It was very odd behaviour for someone of that age. She added, in contrast, Prince Charles was very grown-up about it and simply waited for the Queen to step in. Ms McGowan, , worked at the Palace from  to , and said the strangest thing was there was nothing special about the bathroom, but rather Andrew seemed to resent Charles being regarded as superior.  He arrived first and put his toiletries in a bathroom that wasnapost opposite his bedroom, she said.It comes after another former maid said she had no regrets in speaking out against Andrew who she described as a horrible man.Charlotte Briggs claimed the Duke of York often erupted into demanding and entitled foul-mouthed rants which left her in tears.The -year-old, who lives in Halax, West Yorkshire, made front-page news this week when she revealed her experiences doing the job nobody wanted six months after starting work for the royals in January . She described the Queenaposs second son as a spoiled brat who once allegedly - after noticing sheaposd left a gap in the curtains - fumed: Can’t you f***ing do anything right  Charlotte says since then she has been ridiculed in her hometown and accused of selling out.But believes she is entitled to speak about what happened to me even though it was years ago.Charlotte has also been keen to point out while she considered Prince Andrewaposs attitude poor, she never witnessed any inappropriate behaviour. The Duke is facing a civil trial after being accused of sexual abuse by a trafficking victim of his late paedophile pal billionaire financier Jeffrey Epstein. Virginia Giuffre is suing Andrew for allegedly having sex with her in the US when she was . He vehemently denies all allegations and has not been charged with any criminal offence.
