news uk-news royals-whove-been-ousted-after-"Prince Andrew stripped of military titles and royal patronagesByHarry ThompsonTrends Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  Prince Harry and Prince Andrew could be stripped of their elite roles in the monarchya specic law is overturned by parliament despite dferent reasons for a particular title being under threat, The Mirror has reported. The concerns are thought to have emerged due to the contingency plans in place were the Queen, now -years-old, to fall ill or be abroad and unable to lead the monarchy as a result.Roles historically held by five people, known as the Counsellors of State, would stand in position to take over - but among those are two figures likely to cause concern for Her Majesty. There are currently only four Counsellors, Princes Andrew, Charles, William and Harry following the death of Prince Philip.The pair are her son Prince Andrew and grandson Prince Harry who, for dferent reasons, are unable to fulfil the duty. Harry is no longer allowed to act on behalf of the Queen because he moved to LA and isnapost domiciled in the UK, while Andrew was ousted from the family due to his ongoing civil sex case trial - he denies all wrongdoing. Neither is currently a working member of The Firm. They are among the Councillors currently because they are within the top four people in line to the throne and are over the age of . The Counsellors of State would normally oversee matters such as the appointment of High Court judges or give Royal Assent to bills as they pass through parliament.  It has now been suggested by royal insiders that an act of parliament could be tabled to boot Andrew and Harry. It is thought the Duchess of Cornwall could be in the frame for a promotion to fill the role, while Princess Anne and Prince Edward could also be considered. But the pair wouldnapost be the only royals in the history of The Firm to be stripped of roles or titles. The Mirror takes a look at some of the more notable cases where members have received the boot, including details of the two current examples. Prince Andrew stripped of royal and military titles  In January , Prince Andrew was stripped of his military roles by the Queen due to the ongoing court case linking him to the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein and his associate Ghislaine Maxwell. The case emerged after Virginia Giuffre alleged she had been abused by Andrew when she was aged . The move caused an abrupt transition from senior royal to a private citizen, with the prince also being left to meet his own extremely costly legal bills without help from the Queen. Anticipation of the upcoming costs has seen Andrew try to sell his £.million Verbier ski chalet to foot the expenses. Prince Harry stripped of royal titles  Prince Harry has also been shut out of the family since January  he and his we Meghan Markle left the UK to forge careers in America.The move came at the cost of the princeaposs military roles as well as all of his patronages. The stripping of his military rank means he is no longer Captain General of the Royal Marines, a title he inherited from his grandfather, the late Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh.Speaking at the time, Buckingham Palace said he and Meghan would no longer receive public money infor their royal duties and were “required to step back from royal duties, including official military appointments”. He is now known as Harry, Duke of Sussex and although he does technically still have his HRH title he does not use it. Harry, who was born in Wales, is still technically a prince of Wales by birthright, and retains his line of succession to the throne.Meghan Markleaposs exit from Royal Family Prince Harryaposs we, Meghan Markle, also left The Firm in January  when she moved with Harry to LA. She too no longer uses her aposHer Royal Highnessapos title.Like Harry, she now goes by the title of Meghan, Duchess of Sussex. However, her children, Archie and Lilibet, do not currently use any royal titles due to convention that holds only the grandchildren of the reigning monarch can be princes and princesses. This may well change when Charles is crowned king. Lili was born in Santa Barbra, Calornia and it remains to be seen how the two siblings grow up in relation to their royal background. Speaking during the coupleaposs now-famous interview with Oprah Winfrey in March , Meghan said: “They were saying they didn’t want him [Archie] to be a prince or princess, which would be dferent from protocol, and that he wasn’t going to receive security.” Princess Dianaaposs orce  Harryaposs mother, Princess Diana, was also stripped of her royal titles when her  orce from Prince Charles was finalised. Following her bombshell BBC Panorama interview with Martin Bashir, where Diana said there were “three of us” in her marriage to Charles Camilla , the Queen wrote a letter to the princess saying: “I have consulted with the Archbishop of Canterbury and with the prime minister and, of course, with Charles, and we have decided that the best course for you is orce.”Diana died a year later in a tragic car incident in Paris. Edward VIIIaposs abdication  In , Edward VIII abdicated the throne to marry American orcée Wallis Simpson. The move saw his brother, King George VI, ascend to the throne - and start a new offshoot in the family. Having only ascended to the throne in January of the same year, his December abdication saw himto the title of Prince Edward, Duke of Windsor. Edward and his future we Wallis had met in , two years before their marriage, with his proposal for their union strongly opposed by both the government and the crown. This was because, at the time, the Church of England did not allow orced people to remarry in its churches. Ultimately, after  days on the throne, Edward gave it all up to be with Wallis. title: stunning weight loss woman who
story: Stunning weight loss of woman who lived on KFC and chocolate after struggling with griefSamantha Taylor, from Wakefield, West Yorkshire, only started cooking her own meals for the first time in years when her local KFC was forced due to close during Covid lockdownSamantha Taylor lived off KFC and chocolate while dealing with grief and depression Image: Jam Press @samanthaleannetaylorByBradley JollyNews WireLaura Abernethy:,  Jan | comments A young woman who lived on KFC and chocolate lost an incredible nine stone and dropped seven dress sizes in a dramatic weight loss transformation.Samantha Taylor, , ballooned to  stone in May  after tucking into a takeaway almost every day, and frequent helpings of chocolate and crisps. She had also struggle to grieve her mother who died when Samantha was just , and this led to a bout of depression.But when KFC, McDonaldaposs and other fast food restaurants were forced to shut for a few months at the start of the coronavirus pandemic, the council worker began cooking her own meals for the first time in years.And in the  months or so since, sheaposs shed more than nine stone and dropped seven dress sizes to around a size .  Samantha, from Wakefield, West Yorkshire, said: “I thought thatI didn’t do something, I was going to end up twice the size coming out of lockdown as I did going into it. My diet before was KFC, takeaway, chocolate - anything I wanted. Nothing was off limits. I was having food delivered pretty much every night. Then everything shut and that was taken away from me. When things started opening up again, I realised I quite liked cooking for myself and knowing what was in my food. It completely changed my eating habits.  The womanaposs diet is now a contrast to that before the pandemic as, these days, she regularly has a nutritious protein shake for breakfast, a sandwich or omelette for lunch, a healthy colourful meal for dinner, which will include chicken, fish, vegetables, salad and sweet potato, and she snacks on fruit, hummus and protein bars. She also works out four times a week and tries to get , steps in every day. Even after May  when restrictions started to ease, and Samantha’s old favourites like McDonald’s and KFC were serving up food for takeaway again, the woman stuck rigidly to her new diet. Samantha was always larger than her peers when she was growing up. She piled on more and more weight though when her mother died.  She continued: “Even as a child, I remember being overweight. I went on a school trip when I was about seven and we did so much walking, I came back and my mum hardly recognised me. “When I was , my mum passed away very suddenly and I became afor my two sisters. “Eating was just about convenience and as I slid deeper into depression, I ate what I wanted to make myself feel good because nothing  really did. “No one could tell me what I should and shouldn’t eat because I was an adult, looking after two kids.” Samantha had tried to lose weight at dferent points in her le but had never managed to do it in a sustainable way.  She said: “In , one of my best friends got married and I was asked to be a bridesmaid alongside girls who were a size . We ordered these dresses online and I got a size . “It arrived and mine was too small to fasten so I took it to a seamstress but she looked at it and looked at me and told me there just wasn’t enough material. “I searched for a bigger size but it was the biggest they went so I knew the only way I could go to the wedding was to lose weight.  “I went full throttle lost two and a half stone in six weeks and went to the wedding but I did it in a really unsustainable way and I couldn’t keep it up. After the wedding, I went straight back to how I was eating before. But now I’m exercising four to five times a week and don’t feel tired. Before I would want to nap all the time and I just didn’t have the energy for little things like cleaning. “You don’t realise how bad things were until you’re not in it any more. “I feel like I am the person I always should have been now.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON KFCChocolateWeight loss success stories" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: teen girl could internally decapitated
story: Exclusive: Teen girl could be internally decapitated at any time due to walking death sentenceAllesha Barnfield, from Highfields, South Yorkshire, could become paralysed or internally decapitated at any moment, due to a rare condition which is pulling her brain into her spinal canalAllesha and her boyfriend Kieran, who she is rarely able to see because or her crippling condition Image: CollectByHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsA teenager who feels like a ‘walking death sentence’ is desperately fighting for brain surgery to stop a rare condition internally aposdecapitatingapos her.Allesha Barnfield, , started looking for answers three years ago, when her daily headaches became so crippling that she was bed bound and couldn’t bear noise or light. The former college student, from Highfields, South Yorkshire, had been studying law with dreams of going to university and becoming a lawyer - but they were crushed overnight when she was diagnosed with Chiari Malformation.The condition, which causes ligaments in the spine to be tense and tighter than usual, sees the brain tissue of its victims pulled into their spinal cord and can eventually lead to paralysis. It can lead to so-called internal decapitation, when the ligaments that connect the skull to the spine are severed. Petried by the prognosis, Allesha has opted not to be told by doctors how long she has before this happens. Have you got an inspiring story to tell  Email webnews@mirror She said: “This condition has ruined my le. I had dreams of becoming a lawyer and going to university but I can’t go anymore. “I spend every day confined in my room in complete darkness because I can’t bear the light. “I find the smallest noises excruciatingly painful, even when someone is talking to me I have to ask them to whisper. “When they told me what would eventually happen to me I just broke down. “I asked them not to tell me how long I had based on my scans because I just don’t think I can handle knowing. I feel like a walking death sentence.”Allesha, who lives with her sister and was diagnosed by an NHS doctor in September , is not eligible for surgery on the health service.The teen took matters into her own hands when she claimed that teachers and doctors refused to accept she was really suffering.  Allesha said: “It wasnapost until  that I started getting these horrible headaches. “I have had migraines before but I knew that these weren’t migraines because I could physically feel the back of my head shocking me. “It started out as once a week but then it got to the point where it was everyday, all day. “I took myself to the doctors and I was desperately trying to get people to believe me and listen to me. “I felt like I was being treated like a child, which I know I am but I also know my own body “Eventually one GP finally listened to me and I was referred for an MRI and to a neurosurgeon. “He told me I had Chiari Malformation but never really explained what it was or what that meant.” After researching Chiari Malformation, Allesha discovered a clinic in Barcelona who are offering a new kind of surgery which promises to eliminate the condition for its victims altogether. In the UK, surgeons use a method called decompression surgery whereby a piece of bone is removed from the spinal cord to relieve the pressure - but there is a risk that the tension will build up again causing the same problem in future. At the Filum System clinic, Spanish doctors say their minimally invasive technique allows them ‘eliminate the root cause and stop further progression of the condition’.  But the costly procedure will set back Allesha £, who has now set up a GoFundMe to cover the procedure and medical expenses.Allesha said: “I suffer with crippling back pain and neck pain, sickness and fatigue. “Before this started I was about to start volunteering in a law firm and I was at college but I had to quit. “From the very beginning I have been dealing with this by myself. “To get this surgery and have my le back would mean everything, I just want to be alive.”The NHS was approached for comment.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSBack painTeenagersPeople" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: teen handed 15 year sentence
story: Teen handed -year sentence for stabbing of Reece Tansey, , in planned attackReece Tansey was stabbed in the early hours of May , , in Bolton before going on to desperately bang on the door of a nearby house to plead for helpPolice arrived at the scene minutes later and Reece was rushed to Salford Royal Hospital, where he was pronounced dead at .am Image: MEN MEDIAByAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Jan A teenage attacker who was found guilty of murdering Bolton schoolboy Reece Tansey has been handed a -year sentence. Another boy, found guilty of manslaughter for his part in the brutal stabbing of -year-old Reece, was jailed for six years. A court heard that the attackers - named Boy A and Boy B for legal reasons - had agreed to meet up in the early hours of May  in Walker Avenue, Bolton, because of an escalating dispute between Boy B and a friend of the victim. But when Reece arrived he was stabbed six times by Boy A. He banged on the door of a nearby house desperately pleading for help before falling to the ground. And, having been discovered by two men, he used his final breath to tell them the names of his killers.  Police arrived at the scene minutes later and Reece was rushed to Salford Royal Hospital, where he was pronounced dead at .am. A pathologist concluded his death was caused by multiple stab wounds, which were likely to have been inflicted by a kne with a -cm blade. After fleeing the scene, Boy A sent a Snapchat video of himself carrying a kne covered in blood, accompanied by the word muppet. He later sent a message to Boy B, which read: I thought it only went through his coat so I kept doing it. Adding: Heaposs dead now. Boy B responded with a laughing emoji.  Both teenagers appeared at a sentencing hearing at Manchester Crown Court todaywhere judge Justice Farbey was told there was a long-standing hate between Boy B and Reece, and Boy A had been brought into the dispute as support. During a three-week trial, jurors heard that the two boys had goaded Reece and his friend into meeting them, but he was initially reluctant. The court heard he had sent a message to his friend, which read: Getting brought into your s* again. Ainapost in no f**** mood. All four boys eventually agreed to meet that night and Reece left home and headed to the rendezvous point near Great Lever Park. But as Reece was en route, his friend informed him that he had decided to stay in bed.  Before the trial Boy A admitted to killing Reece but denied murder. Boy B admitted he was there but denied killing Reece or knowing Boy A had a kne. Richard Wright QC, who represented Boy A in the trial, told the court how the dispute was part of a petty subculture brought on via social media. Mr Wright said: It is a fact that they were all young people and a fact that their culture, that all of them engaged in, driven by social media led to them meeting up. He added: It might be said that all were particularly vulnerable due to their age, from being drawn into this petty sub-culture of social media interactions and bravado. They were all vulnerable to that and unfortunately one of them lost their le.  In a victim statement read out in court, Reeceaposs mum Laura said: Reece was our -year-old son, he made us smile, he made us laugh, he made us tear our hair out at times, a typical teenage lad, but he was ours. Reece was fiercely protective of his mum and little brother and saw himself as the man of the house. His dad saw him as his best friend. Reece was simply our world, and his death has devastated us beyond belief. Boy A was handed a -year-old sentence while Boy B was jailed for six years.Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Court caseHospitalsCrown courtMurder trialCrimeTeenagersKne crime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news uk-weather-forecast-exact-date-"UK weather: Met Office forecasts frosty conditions across UKByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsBrits are set for a frosty start to the weekend but temperatures will be milder before an Arctic plunge at the end of the month where there is expected to be heavy snow and icy conditions. People have had to wrap up warm this week with temperatures dropping down to -C on Friday but while the mercury is starting to rise, the winter is not yet over. Maps for WXCharts show that temperatures are set to drop to sub zero around January  and the first week of February is expected to see heavy snow fall. On February  the mercury could fall to as low as -C in Scotland while there could be up to cm of snow in the far north west of the UK. In England there could be up to eight centimetres falling in Manchester.  Looking to this weekend it will be cold and cloudy for many areas with a high pressure but without the severe sub zero temperatures.“For most the winds are going to be light but there is likely to be a lot of cloud about,” said Met Office forecaster Alex Deakin.“For most we will be staying above freezing thanks to that cloud. The thick cloud in the North West still bringing a bit of drizzle and rain for the Highland and the western isles, quite breezy here as well so that will keep the temperatures up here to C or C. Most towns or cities C or C and as I said some pockets of frost are still possible where the skies stay clear. And where the skies stay clear it should lead to some sunshine on Saturday morning but that will be in short supply.”  It is likely to be cloudy for most with the sunny spells more likely in the south of the country. There could be rain in the north west of England while in Scotland with the cloud covering it will be far milder with temperatures possibly up to C. It will continue to get milder going into Sunday. Mr Deakin continued: “Similar story for Sunday with some breaks in the cloud so some sunshine possible for some parts. “Temperatures will get up to C or C a little higherwe do see any spells of sunshine coming through.  Today: Cloudy across many areas, especially the northwest where some light rain and drizzle is likely. Some brighter spells developing, mainly in the east. Rather chilly in the south, but temperatures above average in the north. Tonight: Most parts dry but rather cloudy. A few clear spells possible with some isolated frost and fog. Windy in the far northwest with a little rain or drizzle on hills. Sunday: Cloudy and windy in the northwest with further rain or drizzle on hills. Dry but often rather cloudy where, though a few sunny spells are possible. Outlook for Monday to Wednesday: Often cloudy, dry for most central and southern parts of the country rather cold. Patchy frost and fog, most likely Tuesday morning. Elsewhere, often breezy with rain at times mild. title: mum left two young kids
story: Mum left two young kids alone while she enjoyed party getaway weekend with boyfriendKerry Lyn Caviasca allegedly left her two children, both below the age of , home alone for two days in November - with messages reportedly showing them texting her asking what they should eat for dinnerCaviasca, a teacher from Connecticut, is accused of leaving the children to survive on sweets and Uber deliveries while she went on holiday to Florida Image: Watertown Police DepartmentByAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Jan A mum left her two young kids alone to enjoy a party getaway weekend with her boyfriend. Kerry Lyn Caviasca allegedly left her children, both below the age of , home alone for two days in November.Caviasca, a teacher from Connecticut, is accused of leaving the children to survive on sweets and Uber deliveries while she went on holiday to Florida and partied with her boyfriend, according to court documents obtained by NBC Connecticut.Caviasca’s ex-husband reported her police in December. He claimed both children missed school on Monday, November , and he was unable to contact them over the weekend. Court documents claim he told police he sent his own father to the house to check on them, but he wasn’t able to reach the children. When the concerned father later asked the children whether they had been left home alone, they told him no, reports the New York Post. But after going through messages on a phone he had brought for one of the children, he reportedly saw a number of messages between Caviasca and the children over the course of the weekend in question. Some of the messages reportedly show the children asking their mother what they should eat for dinner, with her allegedly replying Just eat candy and What ever [sic] is downstairs. Police arrived at Caviasca’s home after initial reports, but she originally claimed her brother had been looking after the children - before eventually admitting they had been left alone. Caviasca was arrested on January  and charged with two counts of risk of injury to a minor and two counts of reckless endangerment in the second degree, according to NBC Connecticut. She is to appear in court on Jan. . Waterbury Public Schools district said Caviasca had been placed on leave while the district conducts its own investigation. title: teen 17 takes life after
story: Boy takes own le blaming himself for death of dad who caught Covid at school eventGuilt-ridden Anthony Reyes Jr, from Los Angeles, took his own le after his dad died from Covid last September having gone to a sports event at his school and catching the virusGuilt-ridden Anthony Reyes Jr, from Los Angeles, took his own le Image: GofundmeByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan A -year-old who blamed himself for his dad dying from Covid after his family went to a school sports event where they all caught the virus, has now taken his own le. Mum Stephanie Reyes, from Los Angeles, has spoken about how her family has suffered two tragedies after her son Anthony Reyes Jr was unable to overcome the loss of his father and she now wants to highlight the seriousness of depression in children. Last August the family of five was looking forward positively, having moved to a new home in the Whittier neighbourhood but then they all picked up Covid at a school sports pep rally.The condition of the dad Anthony Reyes Sr, , who had a pre-existing heart condition, quickly deteriorated and he died after being put on a ventilator on September , reported the Los Angeles Times.Stephanie said that before he died, she allowed her -year-old son Anthony Jr to see him and feels now it was a big mistake as it had a very bad impact on him - having already felt responsible for him getting Covid.  The teen was left haunted with the images of his dad with blood building in the corner of his eye and also being the last member of the family to see his dad alive.My son wanted to go see his dad, against my better judgement, I let him go. It was the worst mistake I did, she told Fox . He felt guilty. He felt like he was the one who got us sick. He felt like he was the reason why his dad was gone and we talked to him all the time, and told him aposIt wasnapost your faultapos.” She is frustrated that she was not able to get professional help for her son’s depression and claims that therapists she tried to contact were all booked up.  Then tragically on December  she woke around am and going to investigate after having seen a light on in her son’s room, she found that he had taken his own le. I knock on the door to his room and Iaposm like, aposhey, kid, itaposs  in the morning, what are you doing apos, Stephanie said. He was gone. I couldnapost believe my baby’s gone. Stephanie, , has now been left to look after her two surviving daughters Reyna and Marissa herself.A funeral service is being held this Saturday, January , for Anthony Jr and a gofundme page has been set up to help pay for costs. A message on the gofundme page reads: Hi, as many of you know our family lost Anthony Sr. four months ago, and sadly Papiwas taken from us way too early. He was only  years young and had his whole le ahead of him. He was the happiest kid ever and had the most contagious smile and laugh that would brighten anyoneaposs day. We are absolutely devastated by the sudden loss of Papi. He was a Son, a brother, a grandson, a cousin, and most of all a friend, and to all of us, he was family. At this time we are asking for help in funding his funeral during these hard times, any and all donations will be greatly appreciated.If youaposre struggling and need to talk, the Samaritans operate a free helpline open   on  . Alternatively, you can email jo@samaritans.org or visit their site to find your local branch.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON EducationFuneralsSchoolsMental healthCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news us-news woman-accused-telling-jewish-kids-"New York: Woman caught spitting on eight-year-old Jewish boyByBradley JollyNews Wire:,  Jan A young woman shouted Hitler should have killed you all at three Jewish siblings aged as young as two in an appalling anti-Semitc ouburst, police say. Christina Darling, , has been charged with aggravated harassment and menacing, both as hate crimes, and acting in a manner that could injure a child. It is alleged she approached the children outside an Orthodox synagogue in New York City last Friday and yelled the offensive slur. Darling also spat at the oldest sibling, an eight-year-old boy, police say. The authorities say the other children are aged seven and two. Hitler should have killed you all,’ Darling allegedly told the kids. I’ll kill you and know where you live.  Surveillance video captures the defendant, a psychology student, appearing to shout at the youngsters. It shows Darling, wearing an orange sweatshirt, walking on a New York City street and then approaching the siblings. It then captures Darling leave back towards where she came from. The incident was reported to police, who investigated and confirmed the charge on Twitter yesterday. The tweet said the charge was made possible thanks to help from the public.  Aryah Fried, the siblingsapos father, said: I would hope that she understands the severity of what she did. To do it to anybody is obviously problematic but for an adult to do it to a child is beyond crazy. We also teach our kids to look out for people that look like moms when they feel unsafe. And this woman looks like a person that might have been a safe looking person for the kids. So, what do we tell them now A petition has been created by fellow students at St. Francis College calling for Darlingaposs expulsion. The petition is live on Change.org.It reads: I urge President Miguel Martinez-Saenz to stand by his promises and denounce this horrying act of racism, bigotry, and harassment against the Jewish people. If appropriate disciplinary action isnapost taken, an egregious precedent will be set. title: girlfriend refuses dress conservatively around
story: My girl refuses to dress appropriately around my family so now shes uninvitedA man has uninvited his girlfriend from a family dinner after she refused to dress more conservatively at his -year-old grandmothers requestHis grandmother did not approve of his girlfriends outfit Image: Getty Images fStopByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsThere are some things that always have and always will be dferent between dferent generations.This is unfortunately something one man knows all too well, after a recent disagreement between his girlfriend of three years and his -year-old grandmother.Every month, the manaposs family attend his grandmotheraposs estate, where she hosts a huge dinner for the whole family and in December, the manaposs girlfriend came along for the first time.When she attended in December, I got word that my grandmother didn’t approve of her choice of clothing and won’t welcome her backshe doesn’t dress better, he wrote on Redditaposs AITA forum.My aunt told me that grandma thought she dressed, aposwhorishapos. Now I fully disagree and so did my family and my aunt. My girlfriend was admittedly dressed slightly less conservative than the other women but I wouldn’t call what she was wearing immodest at all. I told my girlfriend and asked hershe would dress more conservatively next time.  Earlier this week, ahead of this monthaposs dinner, the man asked his girlfriend to show him what she planned to wear for the family gathering this weekend, and when she did, he was disappointed. Again, it wasn’t immodest, but just less conservative and I know it’d p*** my grandmother off again. She said no, as she really liked the dress and it was modest. I told her that what’s modest to her isn’t going to be what’s modest to a -year-old woman andshe wanted to buy a dress I’d pay for it, but she refused. The couple continued to argue and in the end, he told his girlfriend thatshe refused to change her dress it would be better for her to just not come this month and they can find a solution for next time. She told me I was being unreasonable and putting an old woman’s outdated views over her freedom, but I feel like I was being very reasonable, the man added, before turning to Reddit to hear their opinions on the matter. If you want a future with somebody, stand up for them instead of just obliging by your familyaposs opinions. If your grandma is judging her because she doesnapost want to wear a potato sack, thataposs on grandma, one Reddit user suggested. However, another disagreed: Itaposs your grandmotheraposs home and invite and she has one requirement. I get it her body, her choice but what the younger generation of today needs to get a grip with is you need to pick your God damn battles because fighting a dress war with an elderly grandma who probably wonapost be around much longer is ridiculous. Your grandmother is never ever ever going to understand this hard line. She just wonapost. Your fiance is being childish. Dammit, suck it up and wear an faposin modest dress for a couple of hours.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: im sick mumfluencers showing pristine
story: Im sick of mumfluencers showing off pristine houses – messy houses are normalA pregnant mum-of-three has shared a clip of her messy home after growing sick of seeing pristine mumfluencer homes all over social media, saying mess is normalMany parents will know how quickly the mess can build up Image: tired_mommax TiktokByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Jan | comments A mum-of-three, who is currently pregnant with her fourth child, has shared her messy home on TikTok, as sheaposs fed up of seeing beautul, pristine houses on social media. Posting from her handle @tired_mommax, the mum revealed piles of laundry, kids toys all over the place and mounting piles of washing up - which is, of course, a very common sight for many busy parents.I just want to show everybody what my house looks like because there’s a lot videos out there of all these houses that are beautul - clean, pristine aesthetic, she said while panning the camera around her home. Well this is my house. Soyour house looks like this, we should be friends! For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. We should definitely be friends. Bought a sign says sorry for the mess our standards have lowered with each kid, one mum commented, while another added: I see a mom putting her children before a perfect house. Yaposall donapost understand that  days of not feeling well turns a house with kids into this. We can def be friends mama, a third wrote. Iaposm right there with you. I stress so much about attempting to clean mine plus being a single mum-of-four. This made me feel so much better, a fourth commented. The mum responded: I try to stay on top of it but we’re getting over sickness and it’s a weekend so le happens. Unfortunately, not everyone was so supportive, and many commented to say they also have several kids and still managed to keep a tidy home. Itaposs not a competition and everyone has dferent priorities. A tidy home doesnapost mean youaposre a better parent.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: laundry experts claim were definitely
story: Laundry experts claim were definitely not washing our bed sheets enoughHygiene experts have revealed that keeping your bed clean and washing your sheets more often can help thwart germs and allergens, and has even been found to help you sleep betterYou might not be washing your sheets enoughImage: Getty Images Image SourceBySusan KnoxShowbiz and Entertainment Reporter:,  Jan | commentsItaposs an easy task to forget at the best of times, but you should probably be changing your bed sheets more often than you already are.While thereaposs nothing better than hopping into a bed full of fresh sheets after sprucing up your bedroom, experts have claimed that the average person is not washing their bed linen enough. Although busy schedules can sometimes get in the way of giving your bed a refresh, experts at the Sleep Foundation have revealed that we should all be washing our bed sheets at least once a week - insisting that every couple of weeks doesnapost cut it.And in some cases, you should be washing your sheets even more than the recommended amount of once a week. Experts have suggested that someone who suffers from asthma or allergies should wash their sheets more frequently to improve overall wellbeing.  Andyouaposre someone who sleeps with a beloved dog or cat, then you should consider throwing your sheets in the washing up to twice a week to get rid of germs and bacteria that your furry friends may have carried from their outdoor adventures. If youaposre someone who likes to eat snacks when in bed, you should also be washing your sheets more than once a week. And people who go to bed without showering, or people who sleep naked, should also follow suit and stock up on some extra washing powder.  The biggest mistake many of us make is leaving our bedding on for more than a week, as they warn it leads to us apossleeping while surrounded by body oils, bacteria, dead skin cells, and dust mitesapos. Keeping your bed clean and hygienic can help thwart germs and allergens, and has even been found to help you sleep better. When it comes to your duvet, it doesnapost need washing as often as your sheets, but itaposs always good to give them a good clean every now and then - ideally every two months. Pillows should be washed at the same time, and the mattress itself should be given a clean down once a year. According to recent research, % of people are more excited to go to bed when their sheets are fresh and smell good. So, itaposs time to get washing.Do you have any cleaning tips of your own  Let us know in the comments.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON ViralCleaningSleep" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: people frenzy over new sandwich
story: People in frenzy over new sandwich shoes - they can be yours for £Instagram users have been left baffled by a pair of trainers that look like sandwiches. The shoes stocked by fashion store Dolls Kill have caused controversyNot everyone is a fan of the sandwich shoes Image: Dolls KillByJohn BettAudience WriterLayla Nicholson:,  Jan | commentsA pair of sandwich inspired shoes have sent the internet into a frenzy as people canapost decidethey love or hate the loafers. The aposDeli Sandwich Platform Sneakersapos are made to look just like a sandwich, with a beige bun area and D vegan leather salami, lettuce, cheese, and onion filling.A picture of the new shoes has been shared on Instagram and now people are going mad for the shoes, with some users saying theyaposre the must-have fashion accessory of , as the Daily Star reports.But not everyone is convinced by the £ shoes from alternative clothing store Dolls Kill, and they probably donapost go with most of your clothes as well. title: woman mortified after figuring out
story: Woman mortied after figuring out why she didnt hear back from  jobs she applied forAshleigh Keenan said shed applied for  job openings and was feeling deflated after not hearing anything back - until she realised what shed actually sent employersThe woman was horried when she realised her mistakeImage: Getty Images PhotoAltoByZahna EklundAudience writerLayla Nicholson:,  Jan | commentsAlmost all of us have been turned down for a job at some point in our lives andyouaposve been rejected from multiple at once, youaposll know how frustrating and upsetting it can be. But for one woman, her inability to get called for an interview at around  dferent companies was entirely her own fault - after she made a horrible mistake in her applications. Ashleigh Keenan shared her hilarious blunder on her Twitter account, @AshleighKeenan, where she said that as a teenager she was attempting to attach her CV to ious online applications but later realised she was accidentally uploading data from her period tracker, the Daily Star reports. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. The -year-old accounts manager from Dublin, Ireland, wrote: I will never forget applying for jobs when I was  for months and never hearing anything back, only to realise about  applications later that I was attaching my period tracker and not my CV. Ashleighaposs relatable post has since gone viral and has amassed more than , likes - with hundreds of comments from amused Twitter users. One person wrote: Thanks for that laugh today. It made me laugh out loud. I hope you got great jobs after. You deserve it. While another said: I actually canapost breathe from laughing. Youaposre a legend.  And a third added: Sorry to laugh Ashleigh but that is hilarious. The tweet also caught the attention of job recruiters, who were able to confirm that people send the wrong attachments all the time, as well as other people who had experienced similar blunders. One of the recruiters said: As a recruiter, I cannot stress to the general public enough: please check your attachments. I’ve had everything from nudes, travel documents and even a death certicate. As another relatable commenter posted: I sent my CV under my MSN messenger email and completely forgot that the picture that went with it was me in my boxers standing to attention shall we say. Someone  then added: I applied for work once and was accidentally sending the lyrics to Hurt by Johnny Cash instead of a CV. And there was even a response from work-based social networking site LinkedIn, who tried to see the positives in Ashleighaposs disastrous mistake. They wrote: Period tracker  high levels of organisation, superb planning and general top tier admin skills. Perfect job candidate in my opinion! Have you got a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: woman red faced after taking
story: Woman red-faced after taking picture of clouds that turned out to be snowTwitter user Atousa instantly owned up to her mistake when she realised she hadnt actually photographed clouds, and she was in stitches as she saw the funny sideTwitter user Atousa thought she had taken the perfect picture of the sky Image: sunflower TwitterByJohn BettAudience Writer:,  Jan | commentsA woman was left red-faced after taking a picture of what she thought were clouds - but it turned out to be snow on the sunroof above her. Twitter user Atousa was sat in her car and took a selfie, and thought the sky above her looked just right so she captioned her picture aposthe sky!apos But then she noticed something didnapost look quite right, and as she looked closer she saw that the clouds were actually much closer than they first appeared. Then it clicked, she had photographed snow that had settled on the sunroof of her car - and she soon posted a follow-up image to own her hilarious mistake. What do you think of Atousaaposs hilarious picture  Let us know in the comments...The woman initially shared the picture on Snapchat, but later posted the blunder on Twitter and now her post has had over . million likes. Captioning her second picture, she wrote: “I’m so stupid, I thought it was clouds, itaposs f*****g snow on my sunroof! The woman posted the two images on Twitter, captioning the tweet, “On today’s episode of me embarrassing myself.” She was soon inundated with comments as people enjoyed her amusing mistake. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. One said: Ok but I didnapost realize it was snow until I saw the second photo lmao. Then a second added: I thought you are taking selfie inside ISS cupola module. And the background is earth and clouds. Even more embarrassing, And a third wrote: I once called someone talking about thereaposs an orange round thing in the sky. It was the sun setting. I was used to getting home late I forgot how the sun setting looked like.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. news weird-news woman-sparks-debate-secretly-filming-"TikToker records husband scrolling through images of womenByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Jan | comments A woman has sparked an interesting debate on relationship boundaries, after she filmed her husband scrolling through photos and videos of another woman on his phone. The woman, who posts from the handle @lyjones, took to TikTok to share the clip of her husband sitting on their couch scrolling, with the caption: My husband forgot we got a second floor balcony, alongside a laughing face emoji. Many people think itaposs hilarious that she aposcaughtapos her husband in the act, while others have fiercely insisted heaposs doing nothing wrong by simply looking - sparking a debate over whether itaposs appropriate to look at other peopleaposs aposthirst trapapos content while in a relationship.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. I’d rather be single than pretend to laugh at this happening, one person commented, while another added: My comment won’t go over well lol but I think it’s  percent disrespectful. A third wrote: I wouldn’t even complain to him about it. I’d just slowly start losing my feelings for him and care less every time. But many argued the man wasnapost doing anything wrong, with one person commenting: Am I the only one not bothered by this  I look at thirst traps on TikTok all day long, doesnapost mean Iaposll cheat. I wouldnapost care about my husband looking at girls he could never pull. Hell, he barely pulled me, another commenter joked. Fortunately, she doesnapost seem to be taking it too seriously, as in a follow up clip she decided to take a followeraposs advice and unleash the Nerf gun on him, which seems like a pretty fair punishmentyou ask us.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. news world-news ghostly-eel-like-sea-beast-"South Africa: Diver spots bizarre ghostly eel-like creatureByMichael HavisKatie L Wilson:,  Jan | commentsA er captured stunning footage of a ghostly eel-like sea creature, who appears to be almost see-through. Amy Wainman, , from Cape Town, was swimming off Simon’s Town in South Africa’s Western Cape when she captured the bizarre creature on camera. In Amy’s footage, the creature - whose transparent body appears to be devoid of any major organs - is seen undulating through the water. Amy said it was unlike anything she’d ever seen before. “When I first saw it, it almost looked like some floating plastic,” she said. “But then it started swimming. It was like a dancing, clear ribbon. “I had no idea what it was, I had never even seen a picture of one before. It was an amazing, magical creature to see!” Bradley Stevens, a retired marine science professor, formerly of the University of Maryland Eastern Shore, has suggested that the footage shows an eel larva at the end of its larval stage. He said: “Its size and location suggest that it is nearing the end of its migration from the mid-oceanic spawning grounds, and will soon become a normal-shaped juvenile eel.” However Kevin Kocot, an associate professor at The University of Alabama specialising in invertebrate zoology, believes it’s actually a “very unusual” type of jelly.  He said: “Some baby eels have larvae called leptocephalus larvae that look superficially very similar. “Butyou look closely, they have a head and mouth at one end whereas this animal’s mouth is in the middle of the body. “This is a cestum veneris, a very unusual comb jelly or ctenophore. “Most comb jellies are more-or-less rounded in shape and swim with ‘combs’ – rows of cilia – but this speciesswims by undulating muscles like a ribbon.” Dr Kocot said that the creature, better known as a Venus girdle, survives on a diet of “ious planktonic animals like little crustaceans and fish fry”.He said: “This one looks like it has a mouth full of food, but I can’t make out what it’s got from the video.” He added that they are safe to touch, but not to eat, and that they reproduce by laying many tiny eggs. For Amy, the experience was one of a kind. “It was the first and last time I have ever seen one,” she said. “It was something very special to see I have snorkelled all over the world so it was great to see something so cool in my hometown. I hope I will see one again someday. “It was an unusual day of snorkelling as we actually saw several dferent types of comb jellies that we had never seen and have not seen since.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON University of AlabamaRare animals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: least 70 people including three
story: At least  people, including three children killed in Yemen airstrikesA further  people are said to have been injured in the hit on a detention centre following an attack on a telecommunications building where three children were killed while playing footballRescuers carry an injured man at the scene where air strikes hit, on a detention centre in Saada Image: REUTERSByAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsAt least  people - including three children - have been killed in airstrikes over Yemen.A further  people are said to have been injured in the hit on a detention centre in Yemen, Doctors Without Borders said.It comes as the Saudi-led coalition continues to ramp up deadly offensive on rebels. Another airstrike on Friday hit a telecommunications building in the port city of Hodeidah, causing a nationwide internet blackout.At least three children were killed as they played football at the time of that attack alone, Save the Children said.The Norwegian Refugee Council said the internet blackout, which was still ongoing as of Friday evening, would affect aid delivery, reports CNN.  The Saudi-led military coalition has been fighting the Iran-aligned Houthi group in Yemen since . The coalition said the report of dozens of deaths on Friday would be investigated using an internationally approved, independent process. Tens of thousands of civilians, including more than , children, have been killed or wounded as a direct result of the fighting. Millions have been displaced and much of the population stands on the brink of famine. The conflict has its roots in the failure of a political process supposed to bring stability to Yemen following an uprising in . Long-time authoritarian president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, eventually handed power to his deputy, Abdrabbuh Mansour Hadi who struggled to deal with growing unrest. The Houthi movement took advantage of the new Presidentaposs weakness. Many ordinary Yemenis - including Sunnis - supported them, and in late  and early  the rebels gradually took over the capital, Sanaa. title: man sacked being fat after
story: Man sacked for being too fat after he moved his family , miles for new roleOnly two hours into their new managers roles at of the Big  Strahan Holiday Retreat in Tasmania, Australia, that Hamish and Hazel Grfin were given the earth-shattering news that they were sackedHamish and Hazel Grfin drove  miles for jobs Image: InstagramByGraeme Murray:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan A man who moved his family , miles away for a new job was sacked for being too fat.The Grfin family left Queensland, Australia, for a new le and and embarked on a long drive to their new home in Tasmania.But the couple were shocked when they met their new employer and were told to pack their bags and leave when they got there It was only two hours into their new manager roles at of the Big  Strahan Holiday Retreat that Hamish and Hazel Grfin were given the earth-shattering news that they were sacked. Mr Grfin reckons the decision by his new employer has violated his human rights.  And he urged others to check on the role and the workplace before agreeing to take up a new post. The dad said he was told his weight would make him unable to carry out his duties which was discovered as he moved a sofa from a shed at the park,I was told I couldnapost do the job because I was too fat. I was told I wouldnapost be able to push a lawn mower or climb a ladder, he told ABC News in Australia. Iaposve been a park manager in north-west Queensland for eight years — Iaposve been doing the job for eight years. Mr Grfin understood such task would be essential every now and then, but his job was not to look after the grounds or do maintenance work. It was a management position, he said.  He was interviewed for the role by video and sent picture to his employers. Theyaposd seen me, they knew what I looked like, he said. Park owners told the ABC News Mr Grfinaposs sacking was because they there were concerned Mr Grfin would get hurt while working in the park. His new employer also insisted Mr Grfin had withheld a health condition. Mr Grfin question why he would tell them and said: Carrying a few extra kilos, in my mind, is not going to inhibit me. The dad posted about his disappointment on social media about the aposheartbreak and embarrassmentapos of his termination just apostwo hoursapos into a new role at the Big holiday park at Strahan, Tasmania  They had only spent one night in their new house before packing the car and leaving the site. Mr Grfin described it as a shock and said his new the boss and his we had visited them and welcomed them with a welcome drink. Now after a taste of paradise and the promise of a new le the family are looking for new jobs and a new place to live. He confessed the most dficult thing was telling his son Freddie and said it he had been absolutely devastated by being told the they were sacked. title: mum 33 gives birth car
story: Mum, , gives birth in car outside hospital as tearful husband catches newborn babyMadhavi Leuke Bandara from South Brisbane, Queensland in Australia, gave birth to her baby son in her car outside Mater Mothers HospitalMadhavi Leuke Bandara gave birth in her outside the hospitalByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Jan | comments A mum gave birth on the front seat of her car and her husband caught the baby as they pulled up in front of the hospital. Madhavi Leuke Bandaraaposs newborn son was overdue by nearly a week when she suddenly went into labour on Thursday morning. The -year-old, from South Brisbane, Queensland, Australia, and her husband Shyam Kottegoda dropped their daughter Buvi off at day care before racing to Mater Mothersapos Hospital. But the new arrival - who has not yet been named - couldnapost wait any longer and was born in the car park at .am.It was a quick labour, about . hours, Mrs Bandara is quoted as saying in a hospital press release. It all happened so quickly and before I knew it my husband actually caught the baby in the front passenger seat. He was overdue — we were expecting him on January  but we are incredibly happy he is ok.  The newborn weighed in at .kg. Midwives Marine Pacquier, Carrie Simpson, and Gabby Rowsell rushed outside to help. Ms Pacquier described Mrs Bandara as being quite calm. The baby was already out when we got there, she continued.  Her husband actually had quite a few tears once he knew everything was ok. Mr Kottegoda, who had parked in the emergency area, told local news outlet Nine: I was going to enter the hospital but my we said, ‘I think he’s coming.’ “My we told me she couldn’t walk so I was going to go inside to grab a wheelchair but when I opened the [passenger] door, I saw half of the baby coming out. So I caught the baby with my hands and then I began yelling for help. Despite the quick labour, the parents have said they will take their time in deciding on a name.Mater Mothersapos Hospitals is one of Australia’s largest and most experienced maternity service providers, delivering more than , babies every year.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON HospitalsCar parksGiving birthParenting" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Eveningcontent online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Courier. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Tayside and Fe. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Courier and the Eveningnewspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from The Courier and the Evening .Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access The Courier and the EveningePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to The Courier or the EveningePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on    Monday – Friday, am – pm, or email.Your subscription to The Courier will allow you to access all of the Eveningstories which are now available on The Courier website. All of the best Eveningcontent, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on The Courier website and will be available for you as part of your subscription. If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Courier ePaper.The new website is now live. Eveningcontent can now be found on The Courier website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. title: stirling bull sales 2022 farmers told to pre register ahead of sales
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: royal northern spring show gets green light to go ahead in march
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: scientists join in race to save rare pig breed
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.
